articles.headline: Wall Street’s Most Hated Regulator Faces a Fundamental Threat
articles.snippet: Rohit Chopra, who leads the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, says he is simply enforcing the law. Bankers call him reckless — a “regulator gone rogue.”
articles.abstract: Rohit Chopra, who leads the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, says he is simply enforcing the law. Bankers call him reckless — a “regulator gone rogue.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Rohit Chopra became one of the most powerful financial regulators by pairing bark with bite. As director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, he has attacked — often with a hammer — the perpetrators of what he considers injustices against everyday Americans.

articles.headline: A Battered Supreme Court Returns to Confront a Challenging Docket
articles.snippet: The justices will explore the scope of the Second Amendment, the fate of the administrative state and limits on free speech on the internet.
articles.abstract: The justices will explore the scope of the Second Amendment, the fate of the administrative state and limits on free speech on the internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court returns to the bench on Monday, it will face a docket filled with unfinished business. The justices will revisit issues like gun rights, government power, race and free speech even as they are shadowed by intense scrutiny of their conduct off the bench.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Abbie VanSickle

articles.headline: He’s a Dab of Glue in a Broken City. Can He Hold It Together?
articles.snippet: In America’s overwhelmed downtowns, private security guards like Michael Bock have become the solution of last resort.
articles.abstract: In America’s overwhelmed downtowns, private security guards like Michael Bock have become the solution of last resort.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Bock was still on his way into work for his shift as a private security guard when he came upon his first emergency of the day. He drove into downtown Portland, Ore., a little after 6 a.m., and saw a man swinging a hatchet and chasing someone into the street. Bock, 46, pulled over and rolled down his window. “Security!” he yelled. “Can we please settle down?”
articles.byline: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff

articles.headline: Inside McCarthy’s Shutdown Turnabout That Left His Speakership at Risk
articles.snippet: The Republican speaker opted to keep the government open the only way he could — by partnering with Democrats — in a surprise reversal that left him as politically vulnerable as ever.
articles.abstract: The Republican speaker opted to keep the government open the only way he could — by partnering with Democrats — in a surprise reversal that left him as politically vulnerable as ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: Speaker Kevin McCarthy began the final day before a government shutdown pinned against the ropes, facing dim prospects of passing any stopgap funding measure to avert the crisis that was to go into effect when the clock struck 12:01 a.m. on Sunday.

articles.headline: Trailblazer, Role Model, Mentor: Feinstein’s Impact on Women in Office
articles.snippet: When Dianne Feinstein was elected in 1992, only two women were in the U.S. Senate. There were 25 on the day she died.
articles.abstract: When Dianne Feinstein was elected in 1992, only two women were in the U.S. Senate. There were 25 on the day she died.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dianne Feinstein had several lifetimes’ worth of accomplishments by the time she died on Thursday at 90. She was pivotal in crafting a decade-long bipartisan assault weapons ban. She helped lead the congressional response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and questioned the Central Intelligence Agency for its use of torture. As mayor of San Francisco, she led her hometown through years of tumult.

articles.headline: An Ancient City, Now in Ruins, Struggles to Keep Its Soul
articles.snippet: Seven months after powerful earthquakes battered the historic city of Antakya in southern Turkey, life feels temporary as residents await reconstruction.
articles.abstract: Seven months after powerful earthquakes battered the historic city of Antakya in southern Turkey, life feels temporary as residents await reconstruction.
articles.lead_paragraph: The businessman fondly recalled his bakery and cafe in the ancient Turkish city of Antakya, where his staff made bread, cakes and cookies and locals gathered for breakfast, coffee and ice cream.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Nimet Kirac and Nicole Tung

articles.headline: They Ran for a Better Life, Straight Into a Wildfire
articles.snippet: Greek authorities assumed the victims were asylum seekers because no one was looking for missing people locally. And for more than a month, their identities, and the circumstances of their deaths, remained a mystery.
articles.abstract: Greek authorities assumed the victims were asylum seekers because no one was looking for missing people locally. And for more than a month, their identities, and the circumstances of their deaths, remained a mystery.
articles.lead_paragraph: As they traversed the harsh, wooded terrain in northeastern Greece, the 18 asylum seekers were presented with an agonizing dilemma: Take the safer route through villages and over highways, but into the arms of the Greek authorities, or travel through the forests and fields being ravaged by Europe’s largest recorded wildfire.

articles.headline: Longtime Union Leader Steps Fully Into Hollywood’s Spotlight
articles.snippet: Duncan Crabtree-Ireland, the lead negotiator for SAG-AFTRA, will be a key player as the guild begins talks with the studios again on Monday.
articles.abstract: Duncan Crabtree-Ireland, the lead negotiator for SAG-AFTRA, will be a key player as the guild begins talks with the studios again on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Duncan Crabtree-Ireland, the executive director and chief negotiator for the actors’ union, has spent the past two decades toiling behind the scenes during contract talks. The spotlight, he knows, is for the SAG-AFTRA president, usually a well-known performer like the current office holder, Fran Drescher.

articles.headline: How a Pricing Change Led to a Revolt by Unity’s Video Game Developers
articles.snippet: In an industry where customers are slow to trust and quick to criticize, a new fee from Unity infuriated studios that use its platform.
articles.abstract: In an industry where customers are slow to trust and quick to criticize, a new fee from Unity infuriated studios that use its platform.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Riccitiello probably should have seen the outrage coming.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: Crypto Goes on Trial, as Sam Bankman-Fried Faces His Reckoning
articles.snippet: The FTX founder’s uphill court battle starts Tuesday, after he has come to symbolize everything that went wrong with the cryptocurrency industry.
articles.abstract: The FTX founder’s uphill court battle starts Tuesday, after he has come to symbolize everything that went wrong with the cryptocurrency industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the Sam Bankman-Fried fraud trial.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Who’s Rooting Hardest for a Sam Bankman-Fried Conviction? The Crypto Industry.
articles.snippet: Crypto insiders, who have been trying to distance themselves from the FTX founder, are united in their zeal to see Mr. Bankman-Fried held to account.
articles.abstract: Crypto insiders, who have been trying to distance themselves from the FTX founder, are united in their zeal to see Mr. Bankman-Fried held to account.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the Sam Bankman-Fried fraud trial.

articles.headline: Vatican Assembly Puts the Church’s Most Sensitive Issues on the Table
articles.snippet: Pope Francis’ calls for open-minded discussion will be tested this week as bishops meet with lay people, including women, to debate topics such as married priests and the blessing of gay couples.
articles.abstract: Pope Francis’ calls for open-minded discussion will be tested this week as bishops meet with lay people, including women, to debate topics such as married priests and the blessing of gay couples.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout his decade as leader of the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Francis has allowed debates on previously taboo topics and set in motion subtle shifts toward liberalizing changes that have enraged conservatives for going too far and frustrated progressives for not going far enough.

articles.headline: Gaetz Moves to Oust McCarthy, Threatening His Grip on the Speakership
articles.snippet: The move forces a vote within days on whether to keep the speaker in his post, a challenge that only two other House speakers have faced in the history of the chamber.
articles.abstract: The move forces a vote within days on whether to keep the speaker in his post, a challenge that only two other House speakers have faced in the history of the chamber.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida moved on Monday to oust Speaker Kevin McCarthy from his post in an act of vengeance that posed the clearest threat yet to Mr. McCarthy’s tenure and could plunge the House into chaos.

articles.headline: China Evergrande’s Founder: From Rags to Riches to Under Investigation
articles.snippet: Hui Ka Yan, who grew up poor in the countryside, was a symbol of China’s economic rise. With Evergrande teetering, his future is uncertain, too.
articles.abstract: Hui Ka Yan, who grew up poor in the countryside, was a symbol of China’s economic rise. With Evergrande teetering, his future is uncertain, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hui Ka Yan founded the real estate behemoth China Evergrande. His promise to transform rural villages to metropolises with middle-class comforts made him one of China’s wealthiest people. He rubbed shoulders with officials in the highest levels of government, celebrating the Communist Party’s 100th anniversary in 2021 at Tiananmen Square.
